08 vintage bottled in 11.  Cloudy yellow pour with a decent white head.  Lemon, grass, funk, and wet hay aromas.  Lemon, apricot, tangerine, and brett notes.  Dry with mild tartness and good carbonation.  A bit acidic with wonderful balance.

Bottle bought @ Ølbutikken. Pours slightly hazy golden with a small creamy white head that dissipates rather quickly without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is sour with apples, lemon juice, horseblanket, hay, leather, lemon zest, unripe currants, sweat and brett. Taste is very sour with lemon juice, grapefruit juice, hay, leather, green apples, grape zest and gooseberries. Mouthfeel is dry, tart and medium to full bodied. Finish is tart with grapefruit juice, lemon zest and unripe berries.

75 cl bottle consumed on May 4, 2012. Thanks to _angst_!2008 vintage, bottled on 21 April 2011BB 2031Hazy golden color, small white head. acidic, sour, apple, tart scent. Oh so sour, oh so nice, very fresh and tasty, mmm, taste. Spritzy mouthfeel, a very low bitterness.Damnit its so damn tasty! And so hard for me to get more of!

2008 model in a 0.75l bottle @ Patricks, Kristiansand. A light blurry golden one with a big lasting and heavy lacing white head. On the aroma this is never to sour or bretty, its just subtly delicate with lots of small hints of many things. Hard to tare them apart, but its light fruity and leafy, some almost grassy and apricot-hints. Really nice. Its average to lively carbonated. The flavors are also just so integrated. Melting together a symphony of subtle-sourness and fruity-sweetness. Hard to tell what it tastes, but right now this tastes just excellent fantastic! Yeah, a true winner! One of those you can just drink and drink and drink... Will definitely have this again! 29.03.2012

Bottle (2008) from Vinmonopolet in Valkendorfsgate, Bergen. My second Lou Pepe up for rating, been looking forward to this! :-) Pours a cloudy hay-hued light orange body with a medium, fizzy and short-lived head, which is reduced to a tiny (yet long-lasting) ring of white foam. Aroma is intense, near-pungent bretty stable tones and apple vinegar, with hints of cellar must, bees wax, honey and floral sweetness in the back. Very little tartness, compared to the regular Cantillon geuze. Taste is dense tones of stable funkiness, dry near-tart floral hops, citrus peel and bees wax...or honey...at least, some dense, semi-sweet carpet of taste forming steadily in the back of each sip. Or, not really sweet but rather like a shadow of former sweetness, as if some ghost of the fermentable sugars was retained in the bottle, post-fermentation. Strange, and rather delightful. Moderate lemon zest in the aftertaste. Full body; more so than most regular geuzes. A complex, intense and great lambic for sure.
Clear goldblond beer with small white head and medium carbonation. Soft sour aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is rather sour and dry.

This poured a hazy yellow color with a white head.  Aroma was of lots of lemon zest, mild funk, some apple vinegar, spice and yeast character.  Flavor was very acidic and tart, nice light funky and fruity flavors, and some champagne characteristics too as it is very dry. Very nice overall.
gold blond coloured little sparkling body with a white head a sour fruity aroma a sour fruity dry bitter taste with a sour dry bitter finish

750 ml bottle from West Lakeview Liquors (Chicago, IL). Shared with my good friends at Destihl. Pours a rich vibrant blonde golden hue, touches of fiery gold and orange glow with a big cakey creamy white head. Thick and inviting with good lacing, great retention. Great with lively carbonation. Nose is immediate lemons, lactic acid and hay. Gentle manure, barnyard, and gentle yogurt. Touches of white grape, oak, and oranges. Wow. Initial is medium bodied offering rich lactic qualities, yogurts and natural yogurt, sour and fresh. Vibrant lemon, straw, and grass. Firm barnyard funk, cobwebs. Gentle oak, touches of bready malts. Very well balanced and complex. Middle shows some mellow lingering tartness, firm yogurt, dry funky brett. Wow, gentle oak and a bit of creaminess in the middle. Quite wonderful, fresh, and touches of melon, lemons, and vibrant dryness, touches of cheese. Wow. Nice with a firm body, yet still quite drinkable. Would love to grab a bottle or two more and see with more age. As it stands, its still a standout.

Bottle 750ml vintage 2008 @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours hazy golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of classic geueze sour, tart and barn. Taste is light sweet and heavy sour with a very dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft to fizzy

reviewed 11-16-2011. vintage 2007 (bottled in 2009). cork sucked coming out, broke into two pieces. pours a bright slightly hazy golden yellow. very little to no head. very sharp acidic lemon with dry oak. some old basement. very sour. dank, dark, and acidic. loads of lemon sour apple. slight funkiness and dry oak. malt emerges a bit in the back ground towards the finish. moderate carbonation, somewhat more on the mild side. very dry with a lingering lip puckering tartness. good, but not as complex as i was expecting. not sure if maybe its this vintage or what. was looking for a bit more depth but regardless, would buy again. i kind of think the classic gueuze might be a bit better overall.

Fruity sour flavor. Rich sour flowery flavor. Medium body, eith white firm head. Very drinkable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

75cl bottle. 2008 vintage. This is th most Lente-like geuze had so far. Yes, that A4 set the benchmark for me in terms of geuzes and this one was definitely comparable. Same funkiness, citric, tart notes. Same complexity, wood-oak hints. Most of what I wrote on Lente would apply here: "Pours a golden/light amber with a nice white head. Slighly hazy. Aroma is nice and complex: wet wood, strong funkyness with fruitiness and some spiciness. Nice acidic notes, recalling the classic cheesey and horseblankety notes. Taste is rich and probably as complex as it gets, every sip is a different note, stunning. Strong funkyness again and tartness sorrounded by a sort of yogurt-like sweetness. Huge citrus and lemon peel notes. Grassy notes in the background. Some wood and fruit too. Mostly dry finish. Palate is creamy, silky, with good carbonation." I couldnt say it better now. Great geuze. This demonstrates that JP Van Roy can be as good as Armand at blending if he wants, same complexity and funky/citric profile that makes 3F geuzes the best. I know the A4 series comes from a particular situation which drove prices up. But when considering pricing and availability, Lou Pepe Gueuze has to become my new favourite geuze. Simply outstanding.

From notes.  First reviewed 10/7/2011.  2006 vintage. Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip. Thanks to readbaron for bringing this over for Dunts birthday tasting.

The pour is a pale golden straw color, hazy, with a traditionally soft gueuze head. After a few minutes no head is left. 

Light malts, lots of sour tangerine, lemon zest, and grapefruit. Soft faded barnyard funk in the background of the nose. 

Light malts, lemon zest, grapefruit, some barnyard funk and a lot of oak contribute to a very tart flavor.

The body is on the lighter side of medium, with gentle carbonation. Tart and acidic. Leaves some sour residue behind my lips. 

The age on this beer has clearly added to the robustness of the flavor. Unfortunately, the flavor is a little lighter than I would want from a gueuze.

2008 vintage (bottled 2011) - Thanks Dave!  Pours a hazy orange with a thin layer of white head.  Leaves a few patches of lacing.  The nose is filled with the classic Cantillon sour urine aroma.  Lots of citrus and a hint of acetone.  Vanilla infused oak and oranges.  Lovely sour citrus aroma.  Light maltiness in the background.  The taste consists of hay and citrus sourness.  Super smooth vanilla oak creaminess.  Very floral.  Essentially a smoother, more floral, version of the Classic gueuze.  Body is smooth, slightly slick and almost creamy.  For a young bottle this gueuze is already packing a nice sour punch.  Carbonation is right on.  Overall, this is excellent.  An extremely well executed gueuze.  However, the Classic is typically easier to get and just as good in my opinion, if not better depending on the age and vintage.  Now I just need to try one of these with a bit more age on it.

Bottle. Pours cloudy golden with an off-white head. Aroma of lemon, leather, funk, floral, honey and wheat. Flavor is sour and tart with some sweetness, floral, funk and wood. Medium body, average carbonation.

2008 bottle at home for breakfast! It pours hazy straw yellow, with a fizzy white head. The nose is grapefruit, floral, gooseberry, tangerine and a touch of farmyard. The taste is floral, hay, tart lemon, white currant, grapefruit and white grape, with a clean, tart finish. Medium body, lively carbonation and moderate tartness. Very well balanced and utterly drinkable. A great beer for breakfast or any time of the day even.

Bottle. Pours light, hazy gold with average, creamy white head; decent retention and some lacing. Aroma is sour fruit, yeast, cookie malt, and spice. Flavor is light malt and hops with heavy sour esters; tart, sour finish. Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.
UPDATED: JUL 5, 2012 Cantillon know how to do Gueze...... ;) Ive tryed one bottle of 2005.....
Colour of copper. This beer is rather earthly with some cellar, vinegar and different fruits. It is acidic and is sour.
No aroma. Clear amber, thick head. Sour apple and lemon flavor. Mouthfeel is very spritzy.

2008 vintage, bottled April 2011.  01/24/2012.  Pours hazy orange, thin foamy head which fades to a hazy surface slick, and eventually to nothing.  Nose carries bright, tart white grapes and lemon, buttery, finishing with musty oak, funkiness.  Taste starts again with tart citric fruitiness, fairly sour and acetic, funky barnyard with bleu cheese, grapefruit bitterness, and a dry tart finish, mouthwatering.  Palate is medium thin with little carbonation, which helps fill out the flavor in the mouth for a nice feel.  One of my favorite geuzes, shows great complexity and manageable sourness, definitely a great brew.

Bottle at Avenue Pub. 2008 bottle shared with Matt and Bill. Pours a cloudy orange with a small off white head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is a floral and fruit. Medium mouthfeel with a dry fruit and light sour finish. A very impressive gueuze from Cantillon.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2015 Pours unclear orange with no head. Aroma is lovely horsy notes, rural, bright citrus fruits, bacteria, slight cheesy notes, vbery tart and some sour berries. Traditional gueuze smell. Taste has kinda the same notes. All the gueuze sourlicious that you want and the beer is in general pretty "clean" in the taste. Love it!
Bottle thanks to Kyle. Pours semi-cloudy apricot with white head. Nose/taste of buttered dried wood, aged cheese, funk, tart fruit, wild yeast and apricot pits. Medium body.

Aroma is loads of barnyard and leather, brettanomyces, lacto, wow, nice balance, a bit of sweetness, gooseberries, musty oak, champagne notes. Taste is very alike, beautiful balance between sourness and sweetness, very pleasant on the palate. Pleasant yeast and bacteria. Wonderful balance.

[Rated 06/26/2010] Vintage 2007. Bottle acquired on my Belgium trip. Pours rusty orange with small head and nice carbonation. It has some floating sediments though. Aroma is of green sour apples with some wheat aroma. Flavor is not too sour for a gueuze and a really nice combination with the bitterness form the hops. Very good, quite amazing actually.

Bottle 75cl.
2008 vintage.
Pours a clear orange colour with massive carbonation and great head.

Bottle.  Dont remember the year, but it was several years old.  Pours out an orange color with a white head on it.  Smell is fruity and funky, plenty of sour notes are very prominant.  Taste smooth and somewhat sweet with a very sour, almost overpowering finish.  It is good, but I am not sure I could have drank this whole bottle by myself...well, that is probably a lie.
Very hazy orange yellow pour with a white head.  Funky barnyard aroma.   Moderately tart, dry, and peppery.  Lemonade with notes of citrus peel.

Bottle. 2006 vintage. Pours a slightly hazy golden orange with a rocky white head. Aromas of citrus acidity, some sugar sweetness and a touch of funk. Flavours show plenty of grapefruit acidity and vinegar sourness. Some oak and a little earthyness showing through in support. Finish is dry as expected. Definately complex but not quite as sour as I would have expected nor much in the way of funkiness. Still a good beer all the same.

Decided to split a bottle of 04 with foofaa at Monks Cafe. At $45 a bit price but very much worth it.
A - Pours murky orange with a small one finger tall white head leaving small streaks of lace down the glass.
S - Smells of lots of horse blanket funk, green apples, a touch of lemon zest, and some light sourness. This one is a bit subdued but it is still quite enjoyable.
T - Starts off with a big dose of strong horse blanket funk slowly giving way to a mix of bright sourness, apples, lemons, and some damp earth. The finish is dry with a nice amount of pucker, lingering on the pallet for some time. The flavors are all there, although some of them are a little to light for my liking.
M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Dry, funky, feel that lingers long after the finish. It remains light, allowing you to drink quite a bit of it before it begins to wear on you.
O - Other than the Armand Lente this was my favorite beer of the day. The balance of funk and fruit was spot on and I had no problem putting back my half a bottle. Worth every penny.
Bottle from Vinens Verden. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are brett, leather, wood, lactose acid and malt.
nice fruity aroma,golden, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly sour, light body, soft carbonation, dry fruit finish.
golden, cloudy, white foam, cheese, dough, soy sauce, heavily sour, medium bitterness, light sweetness, full body, sticky, average carbonation, astringent,

2003 year. Dark golden coloured and unclear. Has a white head, medium duration. Heavy acid aroma, barnyard, fruity, white wine, harmonic for a lambic. Flavor is heavy acid, a bit astringent, funny soft too. Soft carbonation.
golden, clear, minimal head, citrus, Champagnelightly bitter, lightly sour, thin feel,

75 cl bottle @ Pikkulintu. 2005 vintage.
Rated on 20110729.
Pours cloudy pale amber colour with light head with long retention. Aroma of vey tangy sour peach. The sourness gets stronger on the taste, peach, some citrus and apple acidity. Palate is tangy at first and very dry at finish. High on my most sour brews list but not quite as high as the other Lou Pepes. Still excellent.
8326

2005 750mL Bottle. Thanks for sharing Matt! Big "hello" funk, super tangy and cheesy amazing raging intense funk. Love it! Every other sour beer brewer should stop trying to create anything like this. Popping crisp and electric. Holy shit is this good. This is great, great, great. Its got this great balance between the horseyness of an unblended and the champagne-like character of the gueuze. I could drink this forever.

2008. From the bottle. Poured an almost clear golden with a white head. Smells citrusy and sour with some vinegar. Lots of mouth watering going on during the taste, with more sourness and more fruits - apples and apricots - becoming obvious. Still has some funkiness.

750ml bottle  thanks to Troy for sharing. Pours a hazy gold with little head. Aromas of funky, horse blanket and straw. Loads of lemon zest and mellowed vinegar. Flavor is a nice balance of citrus and funk, with leather and earthy notes. Not a super sour beer, but rather a nice gueuze overall and a perfect summer brew. Flavors last long on the finish and end refreshingly nice. Well done.

2003:a på korkad 75cl flaska. Orange och smågrumlig. En sur doft med inslag av frukt och jordkällare. En balanserad surhet, gröna äpplen och knappt mogna bär. En torr eftersmak som biter sig kvar. Drack en mörk lager efter denna men endast Pepens eftersmak fanns kvar.

2006.  Pours clear burnt gold with a thin ring of foam.  Earthy, ripe and acidic aroma, a hint of oak and oil.  Sour but not excessively so, a hint of the sharpness of ripe cheese and citrus peel, some fruity acidity, a very slight sweetness and quite rounded overall.  Light bodied, average carbonation and a long cleansing finish.
750mL corked bottle.  Poured pale golden with small white head into wine glass.  A sour aroma and taste dominate this beer.  Carbonation definitely helps make this beer palatable.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2012 
75 cl bottle vintage 2005 @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu, bottled on 24.1.2008, no BBE info
Sourish aroma with earth notes and some citrus, very typical to gueuze actually. Flavour is really sour, one can feel it at the back of his mouth. Very dry palate. Masterpiece!

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2013 Vintage 2005 bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki

Pours orange with a small foamy head. Aroma has notes of fruits, yeast and slightly citrusy berries. Taste is quite sour with notes of citrus and fruits. Long lasting sticky finish. Well balanced, sour but tasty gueuze.

Re-rated on 14.9.2013 at Pikkulintu. 2006 vintage. Even better with more aging. Simply delicious, extremely well balanced lambic. Slight sweetness and nice long lasting sourness. Great stuff.

750 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu, Helsinki. 2005 version.
Pours a hazy orange colour with a white foamy head. Aroma of strong, ripe apricot, citrus and clove. Flavour of strong apricot, strong sour green apples and lovely citrus. Very sour mouthfeel with a dry, sour, citrusy finish. Hardcore version of Cantillons Gueuze, me likey.

Bottle enjoyed at a recent tasting.  Pour is cloudy straw with a thin white head.  Aroma is way funky with a light dryness and some earthy hay notes. Flavor is also quite funky and dry with hints of grass and hay.  Very clean and very funky.  A great beer to be sure.

2000 Bottle shared by James, thanks! Poured a slightly hazy pale earthy gold with a thin white head that started at the edges and remained. Aroma was full of sour fruit notes with a bit of tart grape, a lot of nice Cantillon funk and a good amount of acid. Flavor was similar with a good combination of sourness and Cantillon funk with a growing acidity that never overwhelms.

2003 vintage. Hazy light golden with a small white head. Less funky than your typical Cantillon, but barnyardy as hell. Very sour as well! Slightly bitter, almost a bit astringent, reminding me of grapefruit peel.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2011 2006 bottle consumed in 2011.   bright citrus, old oak.  old dank cellar, old worn cowhide, cobwebs, and some light cheese funk profile.   complex.  clean.  bright.  right in my wheel house.  just plain awesome.

750 ml bottle shared by STLWill- thanks, Will! 2006 vintage. I took crappy notes but liked this a lot. Deep, somewhat cloudy, dull golden pour with a thick white head. Notes of farmhouse funk, yogurt, oak, lemon peel, oak, and champagne. Tart and funky mouthfeel, with a medium body and medium carbonation. Great gueuze, and Id love to try some other vintages.

750ml bottle 2006. Clear golden/amber with a small white head that settles to a ring. Bright aroma of horsey barnyard, apple, hay, oak and light lemon. Flavor is tart and sour with just a faint hint of residual sweetness. Light body with mild carbonation and a dry, tart mouth feel. Very nice Gueuze, smells a bit more sour than the taste but nice and dry and very drinkable.

Lou pepe geueze. 2003 vintage. Bought and poured at mikkeller bar...  
Pours an almost still cidery orange brown pair, for the most part  
transparent, and topped with a very thin flimsy film of white head...  
Aroma of mild lemony gueuze like funk, yet a bit soft overall but  
quality nonetheless ... Flavors have a nice genuine gueuze quality to  
it, lightly effervescent. Light cantillon qeueze-like  funk alongside  
a mild grassy bent but however finishes slightly on a thin note. Light  
bodied overall, incredibly drinkable but somehow for some reason found  
it somewhat lacking overall. Nice, completely drinkable, well- 
developed flavors but would much rather reach got a girardin black  
especially for the price. Preferred the nose to that of the flavor.
8/3/7/3/14

Hazy golden with white head.  Mild musty and tart aromas and taste.  A nice rounded gueuze, excellent.

Notes: 2007 Bottle opened June 11

(750 ml, 2007, dégustation offerte par rodenbach99)  Une tête mousseuse blanche et solide se dépose sur un liquide dorée.  Une dentelle est observée.  Le nez porte la signature Cantillon : bons microbes belges, acidité, douceur, et effluves boisés.  Des parfums complémentaires de fruits jaunes se manifestent également: la pêche et les abricots chatouillent les narines.  Les saveurs sont très agréables : les notes douces sont légères, les notes aigres et acidulées sont modérées, les fruits détectables.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen avec une effervescence en accord avec le style et une texture très plaisante, douce et, à la limite, crémeuse.  Étonnante.  La finale est asséchante, une véritable gueuze.  En résumé, très bonne.

Millésime 2007, bouteille de 750ml avec capsule de métal protégeant le bouchon de liège. La bière est dorée la mousse est impressionnant et bien durable même que de fines dentelles apparaissent sur le pourtour du verre. Des sédiments sont présents. Elle offre des arômes fruités de pêche ou dautres fruits du genre (abricot, nectarine), un peu de vin blanc. En bouche elle est  moins acide, plus ronde que les autres produits Cantillon même si on remarque le signature. Les brettanomices sont bien présent en fin bouche avec un incroyable velouté.

2005 label with a January 2008 bottling & 2007 cork. Served cold and carefully decanted without much yeast or sediment into a wide pitcher split three ways between friends.  Pours a golden orange with a one finger head. Smell includes dry cider, funky hay, and lime rind. Its a bit slick on the palate from being served too cold, but that improved with time. Medium mouth feel and carbonation and while not ending as dry as I expected, it definitely wasnt sweet. Towards the end of the taste I got sharp funk with a cheese-like notes in between small waves of tartness that end in mouth-watering acidity. Overall, this gueuze seemed very mellow, but complex and I could see being able to polish off a bottle or two alone.
Bottle from 2003 @ Mikkeller. Hazy golden with white head. Flavour is malt, citrus, sour, tart, barnyard and grapefruit.

Vintage 2003. Light hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is moderate sour - stable and vinegar - and citrus. Flavor is rather sour and moderate acidic. Bone dry and acidic finish. Cleanses the palate fantastically. 250511

2006 Zitrussäuerlicher, sehr erfrischender Antrunk. Es wird wenig vollmundiger, besitzt dafür aber nur wenig Tiefgang. Wenig herb, der Hopfen erscheint dumpf und wenig aussagekräftig. Süffige, leider aber eher mitelmäßige Geuze. 8/9/9/8/12/9

750mL 2005 black foil thanks to Manuele at Ma Che Siete. From the basket, it pours a hazy, glowing, light orange with a fizzy white head dwindling down quickly from the acid. Aroma is massive white grapefruit, blood orange, sweet orange sorbet, peach, subtle funk. Very fresh and rich blood orange dominant. As it warms you are rewarded with mace and wet cinnamon stick. Taste is dried grapefruit, pomelo, lemon tart, lactic fattiness. Bitter white grapefruit and pomelo come in to balance the sourness, but there is just nowhere near the balance and freshness I get from 2005 Iris or Russian River Beatification. Palate is uber mouth watering, so lactic sour that it is near lacerative (I had to drink most of the bottle myself unfortunately). But in small quantities the palate is fresh, fruity, and soft. Really so beautiful. Bound to age extremely well.

2007 sticker 2009 cork date. Its always fun to pop open a new gueuze from Cantillon because if you love lambics and gueuze, you know youll be somewhere on the scale between good and completely awesome. Unfortunately this time this beer was just good to me. :(

Beer was quite heady, forcing the cork out of the bottle with little encouragement. Beer is yellow and pretty clear, the head falls away leaving some lacing on the glass but not much. Carbonation is moderate, the head falls away eventually. Looks good.

Aroma is milder than I was expecting. Its sulfury and slightly funky with some lactic and very mild acetic notes.

Beer is thin and moderately carbonated in the mouth. Its mildly acidic, mildly citric and lactic is the winner here. This is some oakiness and funk to it. Its not as good as the classic gueuze, which I suppose I should be happy about since this beer is more expensive and harder to get but I was just expecting more. The comparison of the Lou Pepe Kriek and the 100% Kriek lambic is nearly universally agreed that the Lou Pepe is much much better. This beer, in my opinion, does not improve from the base. Still, its a good gueuze and another good beer from Cantillon.

Serving type: bottle
750 from Friar Tuck. Rose body and color. Barnyard aroma. Tart cherry taste. Very good. Fantastic.

2006 vintage from a 22oz bottle into a Rodenbach tulip.

The beer pours a dark honey gold with about 2 finger of bubbly white head that stays for a couple minutes. It fades to a foamy head. The lacing is nice and thick. 

The aroma is really light, wish it was a lot stronger. Mostly what I get is some sour horse blanker and mildew. I want some more complexity!!!

The taste is prett light as well, I taste almost nothing on the front not much in the middle and at the end a big lasting note of tartness. Again like the nose not very comples or strong.

75 cl bottle vintage 2003, pours golden with a minor head, slight lacings, aroma of grapefruit, wood and brett, taste follows the nose, super smooth, decent finish, slightly sour and pretty light drinkable, overall very nice.

Thanks to drabmuh for pulling this out at a recent tasting.

Pours a slightly hazed straw color with a white head and bits of lacing. Nose brigs forward a moderate amount of funk, thogh not what I generally expect from Cantillon. There does seem to be a lot going on with some hay, leather, and a bit of citrus zest. The taste doesnt quite live up as this is not nearly as multidimensional as what you typically get from Cantillon. Feel is nice and integrated. Drinks well but not as special as I had hoped.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-06-2010

2006 Bottle. 25.4 oz. Pours a shimmering, hazy cloud orange with a thin, white, lacy head. Aroma of peaches, champagne grapes, subtle barnyard funk and cheese, chamomile, lemon, earth, floral hops, and slight raspberry. Medium to slightly full bodied with an initially intensely sour, tart palate that mellows out into a juicy, vanilla-oak creamy finish. This is one of the best sour beers I have ever had the pleasure to sample. Overall a fantastic, classic, legendary Belgian gueuze. Excellent.

2003. Sparkling golden light hazy body with a white rocky head. Aroma of basement, yeast. apples, white wine, sulfur. A olie texture and an bitter-acid finish. A very well balanced taste. Light sweet, heavy sour and medium bitter. Nice refreshing beer :-)

Brassin 2006. Bouteille verte de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Odeur de pommes sûrettes avec une pointe de citron. Apparence: La couleur est blonde orangée. Saveur: Goût de pommes vertes sûrettes avec une pointe de citron et de vinaigre de vin rouge. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Acidité en arrière goût. (Rating #3439)

Sampled on 12/4/2010. Bottled on Dec 19, 2008. This gueuze pours a medium orange gold color from a 750ml bottle. Medium to small sized white foamy head. The aroma is sour, fruity, funky and barnyard. A medium bodied gueuze. The malts are fruity, funky, musty and tart. Fruity and funky.  Nicely balanced. There is a lot of tartness, and lots of funkiness balanced with a nice fruitiness. Good carbonation. Finish is dry. Nice crisp clean finish. Amazing beer. Will age extremely well.  Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is funky and tart.

01 bottle courtesy Tim - many thanks!  Clear glowing orange/yellow in the glass with lively carbonation and a stark white head that fades to the sides of the glass.  Gorgeous appearance.  Aroma is somewhat subdued lemon, cheese rind, musty oak, and background tart/sour.  Taste is up front lemon immediately followed by tart/sour notes that expand and contract through the mid-palate.  The intensity of the tart/sour notes tightens through the finish and lingers for a good ten seconds after the beer has gone down my throat.  Absolutely intense, palate-clearing tart through the finish - f-ck yes!  Feel in the mouth is dry and precise with an organic quality to the smoothness with which the different taste components transition.  I am in awe.

2006 bottle at the Local Taphouse in Darlinghurst. As soon as the bottle was cracked, the sour hit. Pours a bright gold, with a thin but consistant white head. Aroma is, well, sour! Sour apples and grapes mostly. Taste is much the same, very very sour and bitter, probably the limit of sourness i can handle in a beer. Remind me a bit of sour bears. Really want to try more of the style now too.

Bottle. Clear pale pour with copper tints, a bit of white foam. Aroma is very inviting, very woody, tons of oak notes with something just slightly fruity as well almost strawberry like in its acidity, without mentioning of course the classic farmyard gueuze funkiness. Taste is very tart, woody flavors but with a bone dry finish that makes it so enjoyable and quenching. A really delicious gueuze.

aroma is sour with notes of butter, tea, barnyard, sour apples, sulfur and manure. the taste is soft and sour of apple, lemon juice, barn and sour cream. overall rounder, softer and less sour but possibly more complex than the regular gueuze, not sure which one I prefer though
Piercing aroma that stings you nose like chili. Taste of barn, less acidity than most guezes and an after taste of viola pastilles.
Nose is first cranberries, Apple acid, barn yard and late almonds, feel is mediumlight, carb is fresh, taste is dry, notes of red grape, sour malt, little cooked vegs

2007. Gonna pound a whole 750ml bottle back and hope my stomach doesnt get eaten away. Murky yellow goldish orange with a very thin swirl on top. Excellent aroma: funky, lemon rind, bit cheesy, charred wood, leather, hay. Really like the fragrant lemon and mild charred wood. The  taste is superb - really damn sour, the world most sour lemon, cheese.. this brew has a wicked bite! Aroma update - let my glass warm and there is a strong meaty bread thing happening. Back to the flavourino: awesome. Yes - awesome. Funk, sour, lemon, cheese, wet hay, vinegar, wood. Has an unsweetened grapefruit punch. I think my palate is now ruined. I think I can taste my retinas. My stomach resembles a colander. Excellent harsh finish on every single sip. Thirst quenching. Stellar brew. I think Ive damaged my innards.
Mycket snäll och sympatisk syrlighet. Smakar äpplen, jord och lite funk. Lång torr eftersmak.

From notes.  2005 vintage.  Tasted from a 750mL bottle obtained in a trade.  Pours Cloudy light orange with a thick and fluffy white head that recedes to nice lace.  The nose is sour and funky with good lemon zest and a hint of light yeast and malts.  The flavor is very sour with lots of lemon, some bread, and both solid acidity and drying tannin.  The body is light with sparkling carbonation and a somewhat sticky texture with a long sour finish.  Although the flavor is very sour, this beer is much softer and more approachable than I expected reading about vintage Cantillons.
10/9/10.  Thanks Coleman!  Very nice sour funky aroma with some barnyard.  Good aroma, somewhat disappointing flavor with bitter grain and a hint of sour and funk.

Bottle. 2007 label.  Would like to try this with some age on it for comparisons sake.  Hazy marigold yellow with a pure white frothy head that settles into a thin layer that stays.  Cheesy at first in the aroma, then mineral, and hay aromas that come closer to fresh grass, grapefruit (sharp) sourness.  Not nearly as sour as in the aroma, but tame funkiness, light on the cheese, but nice hay characteristics stick in the flavor as well.  Thinner, very vibrant carbonation, dry, dry, dry.  Nice.
Bottiglia del 2005 bevuta allO Connor di Genova abbinata con pompelmo ripieno di tonno olive e capperi. Accostamento da paura.

Bottle shared by Sean in Brussels. Pours a clear golden color with a large white head, a bit of a explosive opening. A sweet aroma of wood, some fruit, but a large sourness. The flavor is very nice; very drinkable sweet fruitiness, wood, tart gueuze, lively and tasty. The fruitiness reminds me of apricot.

Bottle @ home. Slight hazy golden brown pour, large quickly dissipating head. Aroma is very well, bretty, but in a very smooth and subtle way.
Intense and wide bitterness, earth, barnyard, green apple. Lingers on for quite a bit.

Lou Pepe Gueuze 2006, bottled in 2008.

A: The pour is a slightly cloudy amber color with a nice fluffy white head.

S: The nose is incredibly funky and wild. Lots of musty oak, straw, earth, and plenty of barnyard. Certainly lactic and tart, but not quite as much lemon and green apple as Classic Gueuze.

T: A lot of funk, primarily of barnyard, earth, and musty, wet oak. The tartness is present, but not super intense like other Cantillon beers. Notes of lemon, green apple, and some more oak.

M: The body is medium with a smooth, medium, rolling carbonation.

D: Like the other Lou Pepe beers, this one is really easy to drink. Not insanely sour but well balanced and nice to sit down and drink.

Big thanks to Frank, Kevin, and Jeremy for this tasting!

A-pours a tangerine orange color, somewhat hazy with a little thin white head on top.

S-lots of funk up front, earthy with plenty of mushrooms, a good bit of acidity and notes of sour lemon in the back.

T-lighter funk than the nose, earth and mushrooms, lots of lemon and citrus with a good balance of acidity and tartness in the back.

M-soft feel to it, light carbonation, a little thin in the back and a semi dry and very clean finish.

D-good balance of acidity, the funk is there but it fades a little in the taste, the citrus profile is nice and the tartness is moderate and enjoyable.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Bottle split with and courtesy of Vin. Pours a shimmering, hazy cloud orange with a thin, white, lacy head. Aroma of peaches, champagne grapes, subtle barnyard funk and cheese, chamomile, lemon, earth, floral hops, and slight raspberry. Medium to slightly full bodied with an initially intensely sour, tart palate that mellows out into a juicy, vanilla-oak creamy finish. This is one of the best sour beers I have ever had the pleasure to sample. Overall a fantastic, classic, legendary Belgian gueuze. Excellent.
citrus, herbs, floral, citrus, grape, cherry, raspberry,red, cloudy, white foam, , medium sourness, salty, medium body, lively, bitter, long finish, vinegar.

(bottle, 75cl, vintage 2002) Almost clear, golden colour with a short and slightly off-white foamy layer. Mouldy and woody Lambic aroma with notes of barnyard/brett and discreetly fruity accents of apples and lemon. Sour-tart flavour, light to medium bodied with a dry mouthfeel. Present Lambic-character with a delicately malty touch, mouldy and moderately fruity notes; dry and slightly astringent and tannic finish. Very balanced and pleasant Gueuze. 13.VII.10

Bottled in 2003. Pours hazy orange golden colored with a small white head. Aromas of brett, funk, barnyard, vinegar, dry, leather, wood, orange peel and a touch of berries. Very complex. Tart and dry flavor with sour notes of vinegar, berries, wood and lemons. Awesome gueuze!

Bottled in 2008, thanks to womencantsail.

Straw colored and well carbonated, this one is more funky than sour, The nose and taste are mostly old wood and wild yeast byproducts. Huge mouthfeel, but soft. A gentle giant.

A singular gueuze. One of the greats.
user_location: The Court of the Crimson King, California, USA

text: Bottle (vintage 2002): Almost clear, deep orangey coloured, small stable off-white head; solid dry sour bretty-fruity nose with a very, very delicate malty background; solid sour flavour, backed by a faint sweetness; lingering cellary-mouldy sour finish. Full of vinefar and fruits, but all in all very well rounded.....

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2006 Vintage opened July 2010.
A: Hazy golden-straw colored body.  Healthy sized frothy off-white head.  Decent retention with nice spotty lacing.
S: Potent woody funk lays atop an acidic lemon-pear citric base.  A generalized musty barnyard character carries the day as expected from a Cantillon Gueuze.
T: Bright, acidic lemon leads as a more subtle woody, musty funk fills towards the back.  More acidic and sour than the classic Cantillon Gueuze.
M: Moderate carbonation, medium bodied.  Profoundly acidic with a slightly puckering sourness.  
O: Quite the Gueuze.  Even more age should treat this beer favorably.  I cant wait to crack my 2000 vintage.
Sample at stone sour fest 2010.  Clear golden pour, white head.  Lemon zest, grass, barnyard funk, very sour, musty malt, and dried fruit.  Excellent.

2001 bottle.  Cork comes out without a pop, little fragment left strewn about.  Pours a clear gold with a thin head that recedes to naught.  Very sour, lemony nose, especially after the old Drie Fonteinen and De Cam offerings we devoured previously.  Pungent, sour flavor, very musty and funky.  Maybe a touch of white wine vinegar.  This is quite dry and intense.  Reminded me a bit of Cantillon LH12, but blended with their standard gueuze.  Had a lot of that earthy, pungent bite to it at this age.

2005. Light coppery, slightly hazy, minimal white head. Aromas of dried fruit, citrus, wood, not that funky. Very dry and woody taste, complex tangy fruit  with oranges and some dried apricots. Oily and fizzy on the palate.

2007 vintage. 750ml green bottle, corked and capped. Pours hazy a hazy golden shade, white head fizzes itself out quickly, very faint ring of bubbles around the edge of the glass. Lemony, slightly funky nose. Flavour is tart, lemony, acidic, most importantly pleasantly sour. Some woody like dryness, a crisp finish. Moderate acidity throughout. High carbonation, medium bodied. Fulfills the need for sourness and balances that with drinkability. A fantastic beer for any occasion.
Appearance is gold with small white head. Aroma of tart and funk with hints of fruit. Flavor is souer and funky without being to extreme. Overall a really great beer.

2006 bottle sample at the HSC Sour tasting on 6/19/10. Thanks to Dogbrick for snagging this one from Cleveland for me. Clear gold pour with a medium white head. Peppery aroma with tart lemon and other citrusy notes with some funk. Sour lemon flavor with some peppery yeast and a bitter citrus rind finish. Had some fantastic beers this night and this one was one of the highlights.

Sample at the HSC Sour Beer Tasting on 06/19/2010: 2006 vintage courtesy of JaBier. This Geuze is an effervescent hazy golden color with a medium thick eggshell white head that diminishes steadily. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of peaches and citrus along with a touch of funk and oak. Medium, dry body with flavors of orange rinds, lemon, malt and more funk. The finish is tart and fruity with a touch of sweetness and a lingering Champagne-like aftertaste. Enjoyable Geuze all around.

750ml bottle shared with me by Fred, thank you! 
Amazing aroma of sour acidic citrus! Loads of apple, and lemon with a boatload of wet hay, and barnyard funky goodness! This is and unbelievably great geuze! Everything you could ask for, another top quality cantillon lambic!

750ml bottle shared with robinvboyer.
Appearance : Clear yellow, small white head.

Aroma : Very tart with a nice barnyard profile. A bit of wood also. Quite citrusy.

Taste : Very tart and a bit sour. Some wood. Citrusy also. Gets more acidic at the end.

Overall : Wow very nice gueuze. Nice powerful tartness. Nice barnyard profile. Near the end it was getting more acidic which I liked a bit less. I still think I like the Girardin Black Label better but id really have to taste them side by side to know.

750mL bottle, 2006 vintage, bottled in 2/2008.

Pours a hazy light golden orange with a small frothy white head that recedes to a swirl and collar quickly.  Little lacing to speak of.

The aroma is fantastic and complex with apricots and pears bringing some sweetness with a bit of acidic tartness.  There is an emerging earthy funk that would certainly grow over time though it currently takes a back seat to the fruits and acidity.

The taste starts out with the vinegar which puckers the mouth a bit before the light, sugar-coated pears and green apples come in.  The finish is dry and very oaky with the barrel character making its presence felt.  The barnyard funk is more prevalent in the taste as well though its still not dominant.

The mouthfeel is light and refreshing with a moderate carbonation.  Lots of oaky tannins.

Another fantastic lambic from Cantillon.  Super refreshing and less funky and more sweet than I was expecting.

Bottle, vintage 2003.

Slightly hazy golden with a small white head.  Quite soft aroma with a lot of apples and of course those classic wonderful sour aroma of dust, funk and oak. At first the taste was not that sour, as the liquid warmed the sourness increased. Apples, some citrus. Long and dry finish. 

An exciting and interesting mix of aromas and flavors. Nice beer but not the best from Cantillon.

Bottle, vintage 2006. Gold with a small of-white head. A few remaining bubbles in the first glass. Aroma of tart apples and cobwebbed basements. Milky sourness over considerable wheat/ yeast sweetness. Not particularly acidic, but definite cider vinegar notes as well as grapefruit. The lactic character gives an enveloping quality in the mouth that distinguishes it from a dry champagne or cider. Mildly puckering finish. A lovely and very easy-drinking pick-me-up.

2007 Vintage. Pours  hazy straw yellow with a bubbly white head which settles quickly. Loads of aromas; apples, citrus, ginger, lemon grass,  dusty,,hints of chalk. Very complex and overwhelming. Sweet and sour beautifulll balanced in the mouth with fizzy mild carbonation. Finish is long dry and tonguecoating. Truly an amazing brew from Cantillon

2007 vintage bottled December 2009. No spritziness. Dark amber. Flat. Flavour has hint of cheese but qualities similar to white wine and cider with a nice tartness that makes drinking a full bottle enjoyable.

Bottled 75cl. It pours a murky golden beer with a surprisingly tall, nicely lasting lacing slightly tanned head. Some banana and basement components in the nose. Balanced, malty sweet. Relatively highly carbonated. Residual sugars in the finish which I didnt enjoy much. Definitely not my favorite gueuze. Dissapointing.

Bottle.

A - Slightly hazed golden tangerine color with a large bubbly, foamy white head with decent retention leaving a thin layer of lace with some patches.

S - Lighter and sweeter than what I was expecting. A lot of apple along with the tart/acidic smell. Reminds me of an apple cider or apple vinegar. Some sour/tart grapes and hints of barnyard aroma.

T - Like the smell, this was a bit lighter and less sour/tart/acidic than I thought it may be. Thats not to say this doesnt have those but they seem a bit more balanced when compared to the fruity flavors. Strong tart and acidic apple and pear along with a base of sour grape. Citrus and barnyard flavors come out but it isnt really all that funky compared to others in the style I have tried. On the finish there is definitely a tangy and tannic white grape kind of feel. At the very end I get a bit of a kick of wheat as well.

M - Medium body with a healthy level of carbonation. Has puckering and drying effects, but for the style this is quite smooth.

D - Very drinkable, especially for a sour. The mellow taste (compared to other sours) make this much easier to drink and drink more of it. 

Notes: 2007 Gueuze, bottle on 12 October 2009. This is a fairly mellow sour with the flavors much more in an equal balance with the fruitiness. This still is a sour beer, no question. Good easy to drink sour that has a good mix of flavors and wont kill your palate or overload you with tart/sour/acidic flavors.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2014 2005 lou pepe geuze. bottled 2007. careful pour yields a faintly hazed honey colored body with medium effervescence.  tangy and sour lactic acid and what seems like fruity pineapple butyrate esters (low levels, very tolerable).  oak has medium brightness, and honey/caramel flavored malt lend it a surprisingly fresh character, with medium dryness, while also suggesting a small amount of ethyl acetate (pineapple-like, musty, fruity).

75cl bottle vintage 2009 Pours a sparkling hazy golden color with a large rocky white head. Never saw such a living geuze!  Aroma has musty sourness, dust, notes of fruit. Taste is very refined with a good dry sourness which is very gentle and ends in a good dry sour feeling. Slight to no tartness. Full body with a magnificent drinkability.  A very good geuze!

500ml bottle shared at BeerBistro with garthicus and blankboy.  (Mimimal notes on this one - we were a tad hammered by this point of the evening).  Slightly hazy gold pour with an average white head.  Sour aroma - drool - oak, lemon, honey, yeast - mmmmmmmm.  Taste follows - SOUR, dry, good.  Acidic and lively mouthfeel, puckeringly dry/sour long finish, so complex, so sour, I love this stuff.  Lovely.  Just fucking loverly.

2004 750mL bottle had on 4/6/10. Pours hazy golden with little eggshell head. Incredibly fruity aroma with lemon and peach coming through, along with slight floral notes. Taste was an interesting balance of tart and funk and a touch of sweetness, but pretty dry overall. This has put on a few years nicely and really has some great complexities that come out as it warms. Still some decent carb on the tongue, pretty light bodied and even though there is some great sweetness, this beer was exceptionally drinkable. Great beer but not my favorite Cantillon.

Looks nice pours hazy orange with no head. Aroma is very sour and musty almost like old cheese. The flavour is sour and a little funky like an old basement or cellar. It is very drinkable though and has a very thick mouth feel. This is the best gueze I have ever had.

RBWG10; 2005 bottle
pours golden, thin white head.
aroma and flavors, sour, vinegary, some fruit touch, fizzy, prickly champagne yeast mouthfeel. Drinks nicely, plenty of good funk, brett and acidic finish.
750 ml bottle @ Pikkulintu. Pours hazy yellow with practically no head at all. Sour aroma combined with a sour taste ensures an enjoyable lambic experience. Om nom.

2005.  Aroma is sour fruit, lemon and orange are prominent, some yeast, hazy golden apricot, pours a small white head. Flavour is sour lemon, subtle barnyard notes. Light bodied, extremely well balanced, sour, tart, most refreshing. Great!

Bottle [750ml] at beerbistro, shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus. Pours a hazy golden-orange with a small diminishing frothy white head. Aroma is sour and funky along with lemon rind, wood and light grassy hops. Flavour is sour, tart, citrusy and acidic with plenty of funk, some wood and earthy notes. Dry, bitter finish. Average bodied. Very good stuff.

Rating nr 350 goes out to one of these beautys from the Lou Pepe series. The bottle is from 2003 and from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. The pour looks very sparkling and has an almost clear but yet hazy yellow with a white head that fades rather quickly though. Looks fizzy. The nose is tickling and clearly acidic with notes of leather, vinegar, wet hay and unfortunately a little cork - not much but its there. Most of all I sense notes of very young green grapes..in a vinoes way.
The taste is classic. Its gueuze when its best. Mild and agreddive at the same time. Its incredible balanced between the sour and the sweet notes. The carbonation is pretty high which makes a tickeling palate almost like champange (whitout the bubbles.) Its an epic gueuze - what a shame that it had some cork. Nice.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2011 Bouteille de 750 ml. Arômes de cidre, de citron et de levures sauvages. Robe ambrée et limpide, pas de mousse et effervescence assez faible. Très bien équilibrée et relativement douce pour un produit Cantillon, on retrouve des belles notes citronnées, de pomme vertes et une belle présence de brettanomycètes. Le malt joue bien son rôle de soutient. Finale moyennement acide et lactique, légèrement poussiéreuse.

The reason that I havent rated this otherwise great gueuze higher is that it had a nagging hint of something, which was too old. It wasnt undrinkable by any means, but something was slightly wrong. Apart from that it was very acidic and with a taste with hint of wood. Wonderful beer with a snake in paradise.

2006 bottle purchased at Greens on Ponce De Leon. 2006 version of this beer. Nice bright/haze orange color. The head isnt easily produced. Originally, I thought the beer was not carbonated. Charred wood, cheese, fruit, and some sour/tart aromas coming through. Not as nuanced as other Gueuzes that I have had, in terms of aroma. Fruit is sharp/astringent citrus. Whoa, sour/funk dryness coming through in the flavor. A nice blended brew. I shouldnt have smoked a pipe before this. Charred wood and funk are dominating. I hate to say it, but this beer doesnt have too many dimensions, as I was expecting it to have. A nice Gueuze, but I i wish it had more depth, and for $20 this should be expected.  I will say that this beer is saved simply by its uses of sour notes.
UPDATED: FEB 3, 2010 02 Vintage Bottle. Golden orange pour with white head. Aroma is very tart, lambic has gotten better with time. Very sour tinge. Nice.

Vintage 2006, shared with Andrew Bman1113VR

Appearance:  Pours a murky yellow with an orange hue. No head and no visible carbonation.

Aroma: Mildewy books, must and funk.

Taste: Wood barrel, sour funk, and pencil.

Mouthfeel: Watery and low carbonation.

Overall: This beer was big on funk but light on sour. I could tell it was well blended, balanced, but I was looking for a bit more sour that what I was hoping for.  This beer is a conversation piece, not something you would even have with a meal or as a drink to take the edge off a long day.

2006 vintage. Hazy golden body with a fading white head. Aged, attic, barnyard, lemon, wood and a slight sweet.  Florals even more as it opens. Taste is strong attic, spiderweb, congac, medium sourness, floral.  Light bubbles. Good, aged, lambic, but not awesome!

Vintage 2003. Bottled in 2005.

Golden orange with quite a big off-white head with good retention. Good lacings as well.

Nicely edgy but very well composed funky smell. Notes of clean bretty aromas, horse blanket, aged cheese and mud. Grass and mild tart fruit notes. Lemon juice and perhaps a faint hint of mint.

In the mouth, a quick acidic punch is followed by a massive funky brett character. Pleasant citric notes, grass and apple rind. Lots of barnyard and horse blanket and hints of aged cheese. After a while in the glass, the funkiness dominates almost completely. Gently husky wheat character. The finish is nicely dry with a considerable grassy bitterness, a hint of stomach acid, funk and minerals.

Medium body with very tingly carbonation. Refreshing and very easy to drink.

A really good one. A complex and very funky gueuze. Not very acidic considering the brewery behind it. Its actually almost too easy to drink - it seems like it looses character after a while, as if the acidity mellows out.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2014 Bottle @ Ebenezers. Clear dark gold pour with minimal bubbly head. Aroma has tons of funk, wood, lemon, hay, and other barnyard notes. Also some nectar fruit, like peach and apricot. Flavor is excellent; great dark funk character, and excellent oak notes. The lemon bitterness is rude, but welcomed, and overall this is a beautifully balanced gueuze. Palate is bone dry; lovely mouthfeel. Great brew from Cantillon yet again. 

Rerate 5/17/14- 1999 vintage, huge thanks to Mainiac! Yeah, this is outstanding. Musty but still bright, not muddled at all even with 15 years on it. Sweet lord. I want more.

Clear golden pour with lively carbonation and a thin white veneeer. Aroma bursts with funk and wood upon uncorking, filling up the the immediate surround. The nose presents further with huge notes of farm, nectar fruit, oak, lemon, acetic acid, and grassy pasture. Flavor is a funken masterpiece with huge oak, nectarfruit, lemon, acetic acid, and further brett proliferations. Palate is slippery with fine bubbled effervescence and a delicately clean, though quite dry finish. Incredible balance and power in the flavor arrangement- a world class gueuze for sure.

Pours a hazy sunset orange. 
Nose is tart, green apple peel, lemon peel, feint vinegar, and woody earthiness. 
Taste is deep with sourness, tart fruitiness, the sourness gives the illusion of a higher gravity heavier beer, but then it finishes dry. This is a pretty sour bitch.

Appearance: lucozade orange. Thick white head. Aroma: sour, yeast, lemons, yeast, pepper. Flavour: lovely bitter lemon, yeast, pepper, salty with such zest, its incredible. Such a magical beer.  Amazing.

Cloudy golden with a small white head. Aroma has lots of wood, with hay, barnyard and a certrain fruity sweetness. But first of all, an aroma of Cantillon. Dry and medium tart with loads of tannin and wood flavour.

750ml bottle, 2006 vintage. Pours a lightly cloudy orange body with a small white head. Aroma is mildly tart and has some earthiness. Flavor is juicy, somewhat tart, and lemony with a dry, champagne-like finish.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2009 02 Bottle. Nose is very funky, sour, unripe fruits, cellar, dry wood and earthy yeast. Flavor is very sour vinegary acidic sharp citrusy tart. What a treat. :::::: 03 bottle. Nose is earthy tartness, sour fruits, wood, yeast. Flavor is sour vinegar, unripe fruits, wood, sharp acid. Nice champagne like carbonation. Very nice! :::::: 06 Bottle. Nose is sour, fruity. Not as complex as the older vintages, but complex and tart and funky none the less. This beer ages amazingly.
hazy gold/amber pour.  Tart, sour apples, lemon, vinegar, and funk city! Flavor is sour and full of earthy tartness.  I enjoyed this one a lot.

Bottle. 2006 Vintage. Amber beer with a low off-white head. Light acetic and earthy aroma. Acetic and light earthy flavor with lemon and oak. Medium bodied. Acetic notes linger with earth, light green apples, and oak.

2005 bottle from Cantillon in Brussels.  Just a straight-up awesome gueuze.  Great appearance, bright golden with a creamy white head and excellent lacing.  Nice funky tart aroma with green apple, lemon, and barnyard.  Flavor is full and complex with malty sweetness to balance the tartness, lemony funk, sour apple, and wood.  High carbonation, medium body, and a great effervescent mouthfeel.  Overall this is top notch for the style.

Pours a hazy shade of apple cider with a respectable, creamy head. Aroma of apples, funk, straw and hay. Taste is the same plus lemon, lime, and a nice sour finish. Lingering, sticky finish and good lacing too. Smooth and complex, this is not the most aggresive gueuze but it is outstanding.

750ml from State Line - 2005 blend, bottled in 2007. Pours fairly big for the style, in all honesty, with a crackling carbonation topped by a surprisingly big head resting on top of the slightly murky pale orange body. Lovely aroma, with woody tartness, tons of dry yeast, and citrus rind. Nice mouthfeel, tangy and playful on the tongue. Deep, lasting funk everywhere in this beer - brine and cheese in the middle, bone dry lip-smackery in the finish, and held together by a solid refreshing squirt of tart fruit with every sip. Wonderful.

Looks good for the style, murky gold and thin white head.  Scent is very sour with a light hint of funk.  Taste is also subdued.  Light apples , lemon, slight puckering sour in teh finish.  Mouth is perfect, medium in body and high in carbonation.

750ml bottle

Thanks to buffalohead for sharing a 2002 vintage of this at Mikes tasting a week ago.  This was well received and has aged well the last seven years.  Cantillon seldom makes a beer that disappoints and this is no exception.  The only thing preventing me from drinking more is the $20 price tag.

Aroma / Appearance - The golden hazy body was a result of the bottles yeast getting mixed into the base somewhat.  Oranges and lemons combine in a sharp tartness that is typical of a top notch lambic.

Flavor / Palate - Lemony and bone dry it sucks all the moisture from the mouth after only a few seconds.  Tasting like moldy blue cheese left in the toe of a sweaty gym sock it has that perfect sourness a great lambic should.  My only complaint may be a slight flatness (even for the style) but regardless it is top notch.

Brouwers Big Wood - 03 vintage; funky, cheesy and in your face aromas; drinks dry and quite tart; funky, cheesy flavors are right where I like them; some sweetness to meld it down and not too aggressive; yummy indeed and starting to warm up to the gueuze

lightly fogged yellow gold color with no head, aroma is tropical fruit and some brett/smarties notes,  flavor is quite tart, acidic, hints of citrus and lemon blossoms, very thin - dry mouthfeel, seems watery which isnt helped out much by the low carbonation levels, not much brett barnyard in the flavor, not very funky in the flavor, mostly pedio - lacto sour acid, tastes like the real deal

BCTC.  Many thanks to the incredible generosity of the RB crowd.  2002 shared by maxxdaddy.  Thanks!  Orangeish with head.  Stanky horseballs hay barnyard grapefruit aroma.  Hay sweaty horseballs funky grapefruit super barnyard with very dry finish.  Crisp palate.  Awesome.

06 pours hazy gold with a small, foamy white head. Fairly sweet, earthy nose of lemon, hay, and wood. Not as bracingly sour as expected, more citrus and wood with a light, lengthy finish. Not enough carbonation and rather watery and thin in the palate. Still a good beer, but it is not among the best that Cantillon has to offer.
not much carbonation with a hazy golden appearance.  Tart aroma.  Taste is smooth and a bit watery with just a hint of tartness.  Nice balance.
Bottle of the 2005.  Pours almost flat.  Dusty lemon aroma.  Medium tart flavor has lemon and leather notes and refreshing, well balanced acidity.
