UPDATED: JAN 2, 2005 Brewed in 2001, bottled in 2003 (as stated on cork).  This was my Christmas present from my in-laws, who bought it a year ago and stored it in their refrigerator--thank you Gerry and Tim!  Happy Christmas!  I started drinking this before the appetizers of Christmas dinner and finished after dessert.  It may have been that since I had had a lot to eat during the day by the time I cracked open the bottle (about 3 p.m.) my palate was already well acclimatized, but whatever the reason, I was surprised not to have been hit by any kind of sourness.  (Although, I have also developed some resistance to gueuze sourness.)  The dominant aromas here seemed to me more fruity than barnyard--honey, pear, apple cider--though certainly there was woodiness and some musty aromas.  Lightly spritzy, on a dark yellow body.  The flavor was more of the same, very dry with some apple and funkiness.  My brother-in-law and wife both tried a bit and loved it, which means it isnt aggressive enough!  Acidity built in my gut through the end of the bottle, but of course, I was also eating a ton of food at Christmas dinner so it is hard to isolate the real cause.  Excellent, top-of-the-line gueuze though probably not a gueuze I will return to again and again when I want a hit of gueuze funk and sour.

Pours a golden color with a bubbly head.  aroma is gueuze, barnyard, etc.  Not super heavy aroma, a nice and delicate dankness.  Flavor is delicate and drinkable.  Dry palate.   I like this but maybe not as much as others but still very good.

Brewed in 2001 Botteld in 2003 750 ml bottleClear golden with a dense white head that dissapates rather quickly. The aroma says gueuze though it does not scream this. Light barnyard, cobwebs, musty basement, and some sourness. The flavor is fairly mellow, comparded to some other guezes. Zero sweetness, very crisp and refreshing. Damn fine. The most delicate gueze I have ever tasted. It in no way assaults you but is very drinkable. Yum.
UPDATED: FEB 18, 2005 Copenhagen beer marathon 2004, golden color, light sour lemon fruity aroma, heavy sour dry taste, full body, sour finish.

Rating 850! 750ml bottle from Beers of Europe I allowed the bottle to settle at room temperature for a few weeks prior to a half hour of chilling, served into a Cantillon Gueuze glass. Smells wonderfully sour, with light alcohol aroma, light woodyness, loads of fruit and meatyness. This is incredibly dry, with typical Cantillon mouth ripping sourness, but surprisingly soft acidity. Citrus fruit notes complete this wonderfully mature traditional gueuze.

Aroma:  sweet and sour, tartness, some mint (like toothpaste), some floral

Appearance:  murky yellow, lacing, small white head

Flavor:  very tart bite like a pickle, some mint, spices, some honey

Palate:  shart bitter/tart bite, scours the tongue

Nice orange and amber hue, very nice. Aroma is lemon, grapefruit, sugar, and cookies.  Taste is very nice and  tart, georgous.  Grapefruit, salt, orange citrus.  I was told that this would be somewhat palate ripping, and it is.  Very nice and pleasant, not over the top, just an extrodinary beer.

Pours a golden hue with a small halo of a white head. Aromas of sugar honey, sugar and yeast funk.  Very sour/tart.  Dry on the palate and medium bodied.  Flavors of pineapple, honey, apples, and pear.  Very nice.

Peach.

The aroma was soft and musty, possessing scents of apple and lemon, along with the usual gueuze like qualities.

I found this to be very mellow, not like I was expecting. Since it was older, I was expecting it to be much more harsh, dry and sour than the other gueuzes that are blended with young lambic. Just the opposite really. Dont get me wrong: this was dry as hell, but its sourness was subdued quite a bit and it wasnt harsh at all. It was very pleasant to drink, having mainly apple and lemon in the backround and notes of candy and mixed berry yogurt.

Cloudy yellow appearance, almost beige with a small firm white head. Soft, deep and wild aroma of hay, fresh grass, stable and citrus peels. Sour and deep flavour of hay, cask and hay. Soft creamy mouthfeel. Sour, well-balanced finish of wood and lemon. Excellent Geueze!

Still not much of a Gueuzer, but Im trying(I think it goes great with many cheeses and some sausages).  Light honey colored, small white head.  Aroma is tart, leathery with a fruity sweetness to it.  Flavor is tart.  Champange body.  Dry finish

Bottle, anno 2001
Straw color, some bubbles, low head.
Hayish notes. some barn and green cheese as well.
Straw dry flavors.
Lightbodied.
Bone dry aftertaste

2000, flute: translucent golden amber body with slight animation visible. big white airy head that sticks around. smooth. spritzy, dry, and sour. reading the commercial description leads me to believe that perhaps im not a #1 fan of gueuze. i really like this, but im not sure of its 98th percentile. too spritzy for me, very smooth and balanced flavor, the aroma didn't let me smile, and i'm overall dissapointed despite that it's great quality. i'm confused, please... somebody send me lambics!!!
Warm golden colour with no head. Very low carbonation. Silky mouthfeel.  Fruit juice, lime, cream cheese. A mellow cantillon.

2001.  Orange gold, hazy and topped with a short head and good lacing.  Aroma is full of summer - apple, grapes(?), barnyard - fantastic aromas.  Starts with some sour and tartness, but very smooth - great palate here, a sour candy buildup at the back of the swallow thickens despite the dry woody finish.  Complex and very drinkable.  Thanks for sharing this, Sean!

Lou Pepe Gueuze 2001. This beer poured one hell of an intriguing color with shades of orange, yellow and amber dancing in the glass. It was weird..it was almost like the colors werent combining...they were just separate and happy being in their own little color cloud. There were also slight sediment yeasts at the bottom of the glass. It pours with a small white head which dissipated quickly in the glass. The aroma is acetic and citrusy with sour apples, cheese and grape being the predominant smells. The taste is definitely cheesey with grapes, and tart sourness being predominant. The carbonation is mild, the mouthfeel is full and tingling. The finish is unbelievably smooth given the complexity of this beer. Some orange and perhaps a pinch of ginger in the finish. Overall this was very complex and incredibly fun to drink.

2000 Vintage: An excellent gueuze. Pours an exceedingly shining golden color. Nice head that quickly dies. Nose is fantastic. So sour i can smell it across the room. Notes of sourness, horseblanket, wheat and pine needles. Flavor is appetizingly dry with a hint of wheat and blue cheese. In the afterpalate one might find dill. The best Gueuze Ive had.
G-rat

Bottled: Yellow/orange coloured. Unclear. Has a small white head. There is some barnyard to the aroma. Earth, tart, hay. Nice sourness thats held up by a vague fruitsweetness in the background. Flavour is as complex as they come. Typical Cantillion. Sour, acidic, citric and again this perfect sweetness to balance the sourness. I really like this. Is refreshing and cleansing on the palate, an the flavours lingers long and happy. Im glad I have 1 standing in the cellar aging.

(1998, sampled 2004)
Cloudy, dark yellow/orange, small head. Sour nose, vegetal, some earth, hay, okra, cabbage. 
Bizarre cooked veggie flavor--broccoli, cabbage? Sulphury, sour.

2000 both vintage and ratings. This is how I envision necture. Honey color with a monolithic white head. Aromas of the woods on a fall country day. Dry leaves, grass, light barnyard nose. Beautiful balance of sweet and sour. Dry white wine, with hints of candi. Rose petals and yogurt. Not as funky as some of the other Cantillon, which I am somewhat greatful for. Light citrus and pale malts shine through mid bottle as this warms. My favorite in the Lou Pepe trinity. Thanks to CaptainCougar for delivering this one to me.

Hazy golden color with a thick puffy white head.  Complex aromatic, tart, cheesy barnyard aroma.  Starts tart and dry with a faint touch of sweetness and a thick cheesy finish.  Acidic, yet balanced with a full dryness and lingering finish.  A nice gueuze.

Incredible aroma with oak, barnyard and a hint of citrus. Golden color, small white head, fair lace. Very sour, hint of sweet malts, bitter, the sourness disappears mostly, little dusty, little lemon. Disappointing flavors after such a beautiful aroma.

An orangish color with little head. The aroma is musky with some dust and tart fruit. This is a very complex lambic. Flavor is sour with some lemons and a barnyard essence. There is some sharp citrus lurking in the background. A very complex and hard to appreciate lambic, but I certainly do like it myself. Excellent!
Amber orange, hazy body.  White head - instantly disappearing.  Sourish aroma.  Moderately sourish well-balanced flavour.

medium golden, ever-present thin white head. aroma is slight vinegar, grapes and lots of hot fresh asphalt. flavor is pretty damn tart (bordering on sour at times), lots of carbonation, asphalt, musty as can be. its very good, just not as fruity as id like, i cant wait to open the 01 lou pepe kriek thats in the fridge.
UPDATED: FEB 6, 2007 WCC2-Extremely murky light orange color with a fizzy white head.  Lemons and a little yeast on the nose.  Taste very lemony tart with a some apple flavor, also.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2007 Dark golden sparkling body with a short-lived foamy white head.  Breadily sweet apple cider aroma. The flavor has some sharp grapefruit rind flavors bordering on metallic, grass and straw.    Theres an underlying softness (not sweetness) leading to a bitter, almost hoppy finish.  I wasnt blown away by this beer as I expected.  The flavor seems almost simple, as it primarily features that sharp citrus rind bitterness.

1/2/2007 - 2001 Rerate.  Funkalicious aroma - smells like feet from two feet away.  Intense and complex sour flavor - yogurt and citric acid up front with musky hops and pissy oak at the end.  An enjoyable guezue!  Thanks Jason.
Metallic, sour, horseblanket aroma. Flavor is sour apple and barnyard. Sourness is upfront but stops just short of being harsh, very nice flavor.

2000 vintage.  Super hazy golden ale, fizzy white head.  Notes of farm animals, earth, wood, cobwebs, bitter lemon, and some honey.  Yellow sourpatch kid on steroids!!  Medium bodied, sour mouth puckering dry finish.  Great stuff!!

2000 vintage. Cloudy amber with a tall white head. Aroma is sour but very controlled. Aroma is rubbery and citrusy with some horse blanket and musty basement/wet earth notes. Tart taste with fruit and some leather. Finish is mnot that tart, surprisingly, but still dry. Not as acidic as a "fresh" gueuze. Awesome beer!

Murky, yellow ale with a large, frothy, white head. Great retention and good lacing. The aroma is yeasty and soapy with notes of honey and lemon... mostly lemon. Very sour flavor. Lemon juice, lemon rind and grapefruit juice. Medium-bodied with a dry mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, sour, bone-dry finish. Very nice!
UPDATED: OCT 16, 2005 2000 sticker, poured cloudy gold, small white head.  Funky aroma of horseblanket, yeast and brett.  Sour and tart taste, some apple and a major carbonation.

1999 sticker and 2001 cork.  Clear golden body beneath a fluffy, white head.  Slightly tart aroma with a bit of barnyard funkiness, but more sweet oranges, lemon zest, straw, mint, a thin layer of dust and apple cider.  The body is fairly light and quite effervescent.  Tart, acidic flavors are present but do not dominate.  The finish is fairly dry, but sweeter than the gueuze.  The more subtle funk and higher sweetness is unusual for a Cantillon gueuze, but interesting nonetheless.  I have another bottle of this unique Cantillon alchemikal creation and I would love to see what about 10 years does to this.  If the yeast can take over the sweetness and prove to be funkier and drier, this could be jaw-droppingly good.

Cloudy orange color, medium white head. Typical gueuze aroma, but a bit weaker and more sweet. Taste is sweet gueuze sour, hint of dishwash. As jerohen said, there are better gueuzes out there. Nevertheless a nice beer to complete my first millenium!

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2013 Bottled 2001, sampled 2004. Cloudy orange coloured, nice head. Typical gueuze aroma, a bit on the sweet side. Tart flavour, woody, quite sour, some sweetness. I really enjoyed it, but imho better gueuzes are out there. Re-rate: 2001 vintage from my own cellar. Hazy golden colored, small head. Very powerful aroma, typical gueuze, like a farm, some tartness, absolutely wonderful. Sour, but not overly, smooth and balanced. Perhaps even better than only 3 years old.

(Bottle 2001) Aroma is quite sweet for a gueuze. Very woody and citrus. Hazy, orange coloured with a thin, white, lasting head. Taste is not as good as the smell. Perhaps I expected too much? Still it is a wonderfull brew. Taste is very woody and very sour/tart, just a little citrus and sweetness. Very dry palate.

Bottle, cork dated 2003. Bought from the brewery March 2004 (6). Slightly hazy orange gold, poor head and low condition. Initial lemon sherbert aromas quickly replaced by low citric tart lambic notes, a background hint of sweet caramel and a faint trace of earthiness that reminded me to get the septic tank emptied before the summer. Quite full bodied for a gueuze, with a nice balance of lemony sweetness, caramel and woody tartness. Good lingering sweet lemony finish with some trace lambic sourness and just a hint of metallic dryness. Seemed to be lacking the normal effervescence you get with a Cantillon, did I drink it too soon?

hazy orange, huge head..lemon, dank swiss cheese, and other funky aromas...subtly sour flavors with tangy lemon endings...not as sour and over the top as I had hoped...kinda weak, semi-watery mouthfeel..i was hoping a lot more for $28 a bottle.

75cL bottle, tulip glass, 2002 bottling.  Bread, toasted grain, straw malt (M); horseblanket, barnyard, leather, cobweb yeast (H); white grape, clove, cask wood, and white wine aromas.  Wonderful stench!  Tall, creamy, frothy, white head is slowly diminishing and crowns a deep and hazy amber-peach body with lively carbonation.  Incredibly inviting.  Heavily tart flavor becomes a super tart finish that has an aftertaste reminiscent of really sour gumballs.  The taste lacks some of the depth that the aroma possesses but is still quite satisfying.  Medium body, oily texture, fizzy carbonation.  The bottom line is: an ultra classy gueuze.

(1999) Hazy golden hue with frothy white head and good lace. The aroma hints of sour fruits (apple and cherry), lemon zest, oak wood, lightly toasted grains, grassy hops, earthy and dusty yeast esters. The taste has the pronounced acidic tart nature and salty edges I would expect from the style. Additional tones of bone dry wood, mint, and a taste of honey (had to do it, boogie oogie oogie). The sublime earthy qualities had some depth to the palate. The mouthfeel is lively, crisp, and tannic. One of the better example of the genre I have had, the aging rounded the taste and provided a smoothness not often found in a Gueuze. $30 well spent!

2001 bottle. Head is initially small, fizzy, white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly yeasty (barnyard, mold, earth), with light notes of sour apple, cask wood, and lemon peel. Flavor is moderately sweet, heavily acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, heavily acidic. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent. Rather light aroma with not much going on, and not balanced as well as the top shelf gueuzes out there.

Bottled 2001, Sampled January 2004  Pours a semi-hazy gold color and is topped by a white head.  Sour citrus aromas emanate immediately from my glass.  These aromas are accompanied by notes of musty mushrooms and urea.  A very tart first sip; my lips pucker and it feels like my cheeks have turned inside out.  Ah yes this is going to be a good Cantillon offering.Fairly low carbonation for a Gueuze, though strictly speaking this is not one, as it only has three year old Lambic in it.  This is quite lemony and not as funky as some Lambic derivations.  The brettanomyces character is pretty subdued, but there are definite musty-leathery notes here.  A bit of vinegar adds to the acidity.  The beer finishes with a slight tannic astringency, which seems fairly typical.  My only complaint is that perhaps this bottle could have used a bit more complexity.  The good/ variable thing about Lambic is that the next bottle is likely to be quite a bit different, so perhaps my complexity is hidden in the next bottle.

SLightly hazy orange honey color with a large fluffy white head.  Continous carbonation.  Musty yeast, sour aroma and yes, barnyard.  Not as tart as some other Cantillon products but still very sour.  Enjoyable but not worth the $20 price.

Deep bright red.  Nose incredibly funky, tart and musty, very very sour stuff.  Flavor is astoundingly funky and sour, musty, horseblanket, and earthy as all heck.  Fascinating stuff and, while a bit too funky for me, I can appreciate the character of this one.

hmmm, mine also said 2000 on the bottle, 2002 on the cork. The aroma is a bit dusty, with some fruit in the background. The finish is a bit sour. It goes pretty nicely with the ceviche I'm eating. Trying to drink this by itself would be a bit challenging, but having it w/ a good food pairing makes a big difference.

[Mine said vintage 2000 on the bottle but 2002 on the cork??? - drunk November 2003] The aroma is fresh fruity - very much like a geueze should be. The color is orange and it has a fine head while pouring but then it disappears. The flavor is a fresh geueze flavor: fruit, acidity and a slight sourness turning a lot towards a sour grapefruit. A very nice geueze. Thanks a lot to Alex (fiulijn) for trading me this.

Finally I got hold of this beer. Vintage 2000. Aroma has oak, grapes, some hops and grapefruit, The flavor is stronger and even more complex. A good deal of sourness, but not overwhelming. Even a hint of sweetness present. I found so many flavors. Honey, oak, grapefruit, grape juice, banana liquor, pineapple. A magnificent and immensely complex beer in all aspects. Less assertive as the "normal"Cantillon geuze, but makes that up in finesse. A worthy # 1400!

Honey, grapefruit, moss and pungent straw. Very elegant. Half-moon froth. Quickly-rising carbonation. Light yet lasting palate. Gave me images of sun & humidity just after a thunderstorm as well as melted gold dripping over silk...don't ask me why. Could taste this gem for 5 minutes after it left my mouth.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2008 2000:  Foggy pale peach.  Jagged large and small-bubbled white froth.  Relatively softish aroma full of iron, peach, must, chalk, moist earth, and grass.  Very bright and fruity.  Sits gently on the palate with soft, tingly spritz.  Slightly medicinal first impression, followed by  shades of cedar and grass.  Concludes with a nylon sack, table grape, and peach skin edge alongside mild pale malt husk remnants.  It lacks the hallmark Cantillon musty, sharp, and farmy qualities, but it’s nonetheless another brilliant creation from these people.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: 2000:Cloudy copper. Big head at first,settles to a nice ring. Huge leather,farmhouse,grassy,lemon rind,aroma. Mouthfeel is spritzy and sharp. Medium to full body. Flavors of wood,leather,old malts, iron,and dried grass. Fairly fruity and sweet,nice combo. Finish is pleasently acidic,dry,and freshly bitter(lemon rind type bitter). As it loses carbonation becomes dangerously,drinkable. Thanks for the hook-up John.

1999, pale apricot colour, subtle tart aroma mixed with sweat and leather.  Salty, tart but very well balanced, some grapfruit acidity mixed with its rind bitterness.  A very well rounded beer, sooo good!  Many thanks Kasta!!
Cloudy dark blond beer with a small head. Sour, rubber and leather aroma. Well balanced, somewhat sweet taste with a light bitter finish. Very mild taste for a geuze.

(1999) Hazy gold. Wispy off-white head. Aroma of leather, horseblankets, lemon, sour apple, & sea salt. Smooth, light, dry feel. Very refined, subtle lambic flavour, again, of leather, horseblanket, lemon, sour apple, though with an underlying sugarcane-like sweetness. Finish is refreshingly tart & dry.

Dry , slightly acidic . Salty , leathery . Amber look , rings of white head .  Mediun body . Gueuze that is gentle yet knows what hsa to offer  . Much more refined that average lambic I ever had . Earty , sour and very drinkable .
bubbly gold.  sour metallic, lemon and mild barnyard aroma.  tart cider and lemon notes with a bit of sweetness before a pithy finish.  a very balanced and stylish gueuze.  thanks kasta!

Beer # 2 at Todd's Continents Collide party. Medium hazy yellow with large pale cream coloured short lasting head. Medium sour cider and skin yeast with hint of seaside aroma. Medium citric grapefruit, yeasty and milder bitter flavours. Lifting slightly sweeter finish and aftertaste. Not as intense as their Krieks but almost perfect in the hot sultry atmospherics of Todd's Party.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2006 Venerable lambic yeast and vulnerable dried apples...Surprising, noble balance for Cantillon, so lesser lemony acidity than the regular gueuze...The incarnation of smoothness and reverend, oncoming bacchanalia...3.9/5

A 2002 bottle was crushed in a blind gueuze tasting we did with 17 other gueuzes and near-gueuzes...This one was dusty, possessed no intriguing aroma at all, was obviously not a blend of different vintages, but did not offer much complexity at all...Hops were even perceived, which let us to believe in the wildest incarnations of this unknown substance in our glass...Not worth the cost at all, definitely not considering the fact you can get their regular at half the price...3.2/5
Year 1999.  Murky orange in colour.  Aroma is very sour, yeasty, tart, vinegar.  Flavour is quite sour and extreamly refreshing.  Finishes with a sour and dry.
(WCC2003)(1999 Bottle): Hazy peach body with small off-white head.  Aroma is yeasty, sour, cheesy, barnyard, vinegar.  Taste is mildly sour, old gym socks, yeasty, finish of vinegar sourness.

(75o ml Bottle) Year: 1999. Near headless, beautiful golden-orange body. Nose of sour oranges. Strong cirtus and orange; but mainly grapefuit. Finishes with a powerful sourness that can strip the car of its paint! Thanks to Kasta for bringing this...
Year 2000, bottled 2002Blond color, beautiful fine perlage. Fresh Gueuze aroma, some wood, magnesia. Very dry, stringent, woody. Not exceptional.

Bottle #4 of 120: Has that deep internal golden orangey glow that some Fantomes have; very creamy long-lasting head which I thought was unusual. Excellent aroma; softly wooden, flowery, lemony. Very dry yet strangely refreshing. Lots of dirty diaper aromas, nowhere near as sour as other Cantillons I've had; big bodied firm palate; smooth and delectable but seems to be missing something. Still a classic - reminds me of the smoothness of that first Lindemann's Cuvee Rene 1994, which completely blew my mind. Thanks again to Kevin.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
Colour: golden with orangey shine; thick, white head, quite even, slowly disappearing; beer continues fine, pearly bubbling.
Nose: Woody, tart (yes - even in the nose), lemony, lemon-flower or lemon-scented (dry) tea; slightly sulphury.
Taste: tart, drying, tannins. Citrus zest, green apples, meaty flavour too. Fades ever so gently. 
Aftertaste: Dry tartness keeps lingering. Strange impression of sweetness appears, probably due to disappearance of acids in the mouth - orange marmalade without the sticky sweetness.
Mouthfeel: Absolutely dry (tannins) effect on front teeth and tongue. Slight burning throat effect.

It is impressive how active this beer is, as composed from old (2yr.) lambics only.

1999 according to the label, bottled (or "botteld" on the cork) in 2001. More expensive than Westy 12 ($35 for 750 ml). Not numbered (although there is a label pasted over another label on the back on the bottle, so there may be more information below). Typical Cantillon seepy cork; the liquid under the crown cap smells like apple-cider vinegar. Nose from the bottle before the pour is cidery, but not vinegar. Medium head, lots of carbonation during the pour but not once settled, golden body, rather hazy. Nose is slightly musty cider. Head recedes to a couple of millimeters after a minute or so. A lot of body for a gueuze; almost chewy. Muted sourness, very smooth. This has a funky undercurrent that is hard to characterize. Very soft for the style. Leaves a sour cheesiness on the tongue. Im amazed at the body of this one; thick and silky; almost like a gueuze with the mouthfeel of an oatmeal stout. Somewhat woody. The biggest flaw is that its so smooth that it doesnt have the biting front that I like from a gueuze. I can feel the acid in my stomach already, though. Pretty interesting, although, considering the price, I wont be sampling this often.
cloudy orange colour, few head, complex aroma of rhubarb, apricot and "animals", start is soft and sweet followed by a strong sourness, the finish is very dry - great balance
1998, bottle 114 of 120.  Traditional sour notes, but with a superb smoothness unfound in many gueuze.  Great complexities with outdoor in the woods flavor.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2003 1998 VERSION sampled from BOTTLE #114 of 120 produced:   Smoothest of all the Cantillom lambics and gueuzes!  Bright gold in color, slighly hazy.  Cheeses and petting zoo memories in the nose. Super complex without any tastes really dominating, including the sour notes! Superb gueuze made from 2 year old lambics that are handchosen by the Grandfather of the brewers family.
Very nice, quite stinky barnyard (hay, horse shit, etc) smell, very sour and acidic like there others gueuzes, but perhaps not as goo, extremely enjoyable though, and quite complex and refreshing.

Orange-yellow with a light red tone. Nice white head. Tart and pointy aroma. Flavor with tones of red meat, wood and unripened fruit.
A really good lambic that is hard to get up close on.
1999 version. Golden coloured. Acidic aroma. Oaky with balanced acidity and a surpring hint oh honey sweetness. Sparkling mouthfeel. Bears some resemblance to a very dry well wooded white wine.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2016 2013 vintage.  Aroma is dusty, leathery, grapefruity.  Sweet, earthy lambic.  Soft carbo. Has a complex character and dangerous drinkability.  Original 2001 rate.  Earthy and sour, but not as much as the brewerys other gueuzes.  Still a lot of funkiness, and cheesy, dry hay flavours, and a vibrant body.
